summary: This is a Law360 White Collar newsletter from July 22, 2019, summarizing various legal news stories. It includes a brief item about the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office launching an internal investigation into the supervision of Jeffrey Epstein during his 2008 jail sentence in Florida, prompted by allegations from victims' lawyers about abuse of work release privileges.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned as the subject of a new internal investigation by the Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office regarding the supervision of his work release a decade prior while jailed on sex crime charges.

persons.name: Gregory Craig
persons.context: Mentioned in a separate news item indicating he did not want to introduce a Ukraine-focused report from his former firm at his upcoming trial.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned in a news item about a House Oversight Committee inquiry into whether DOJ policy against indicting a sitting president impacted the decision not to indict him following campaign finance allegations.

persons.name: Jerome B. Simandle
persons.context: Reported to have died at age 70 after a battle with liver cancer; was a former chief of New Jersey's federal bench.

persons.name: Neil Gorsuch
persons.context: Mentioned for sending a letter of advice to a law student, which drew online attention.

persons.name: John Paul Stevens
persons.context: Mentioned in a podcast segment remembering him after his death on July 16, 2019, at age 99.

events.title: Palm Beach Sheriff Announces Epstein Work Release Probe
events.description: The Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office announces an internal investigation into its department's supervision of Jeffrey Epstein during his jail sentence a decade earlier, following implications from victims' lawyers that Epstein abused work release privileges.

events.title: Death of Justice John Paul Stevens
events.description: Former U.S. Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens dies at the age of 99.

keyFacts: The Palm Beach County Sheriff's Office initiated an internal investigation in July 2019 regarding its supervision of Jeffrey Epstein during his 2008 jail term.
The investigation was prompted by allegations from victims' lawyers that Epstein had abused the privileges of his work release arrangement.
The document is a legal industry newsletter (Law360) covering multiple white-collar crime and legal news stories from July 22, 2019.
Epstein is referred to in the context of his prior Florida sex crime charges and incarceration a decade before this news item.
The newsletter context shows ongoing public and legal scrutiny of Epstein's case even before his 2019 arrest.
